an4.69:1.3.eng: The efforts to restrain, to give up, to develop, and to preserve.

an4.69:1.4.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to restrain?

an4.69:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an4.69:1.5.eng: It’s when you generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

an4.69:1.6.eng: This is called the effort to restrain.

an4.69:2.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to give up?

an4.69:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an4.69:2.2.eng: It’s when you generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities are given up.

an4.69:2.3.eng: This is called the effort to give up.

an4.69:3.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to develop?

an4.69:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an4.69:3.2.eng: It’s when you generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

an4.69:3.3.eng: This is called the effort to develop.

an4.69:4.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to preserve?

an4.69:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
an4.69:4.2.eng: It’s when you generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are fulfilled by development.

an4.69:4.3.eng: This is called the effort to preserve.

an4.69:5.4.eng: taught by the Kinsman of the Sun.

an4.69:5.5.eng: Any mendicant who keenly applies these

an4.69:5.6.eng: may attain the ending of suffering.”

an4.7:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā saṅghaṃ sobhenti.
an4.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four who are competent, educated, assured, and learned, who have memorized the teachings and practice in line with the teaching, grace the Saṅgha.

an4.7:1.3.pli: Bhikkhu, bhikkhave, viyatto vinīto visārado bahussuto dhammadharo dhammānudhammappaṭipanno saṅghaṃ sobheti.

an4.7:1.4.pli: Bhikkhunī, bhikkhave, viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā saṅghaṃ sobheti.

an4.7:1.5.pli: Upāsako, bhikkhave, viyatto vinīto visārado bahussuto dhammadharo dhammānudhammappaṭipanno saṅghaṃ sobheti.

an4.7:1.6.pli: Upāsikā, bhikkhave, viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā saṅghaṃ sobheti.

an4.7:1.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā saṅghaṃ sobhentīti.
an4.7:1.7.eng: These four who are competent, educated, assured, and learned, who have memorized the teachings and practice in line with the teaching, grace the Saṅgha.

an4.7:2.1.pli: Yo hoti viyatto ca visārado ca,

an4.7:2.2.eng: learned, a memorizer of the teachings,

an4.7:2.3.eng: who lives in line with the teaching—

an4.7:2.4.eng: such a one is said to grace the Saṅgha.

an4.7:3.6.eng: they are the graces of the Saṅgha.”

an4.70:1.1.pli: “Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye rājāno adhammikā honti, rājāyuttāpi tasmiṃ samaye adhammikā honti.
an4.70:1.1.eng: “At a time when kings are unprincipled, royal officials become unprincipled.

an4.70:1.2.pli: Rājāyuttesu adhammikesu brāhmaṇagahapatikāpi tasmiṃ samaye adhammikā honti.
an4.70:1.2.eng: When royal officials are unprincipled, brahmins and householders become unprincipled.

an4.70:1.3.pli: Brāhmaṇagahapatikesu adhammikesu negamajānapadāpi tasmiṃ samaye adhammikā honti.
an4.70:1.3.eng: When brahmins and householders are unprincipled, the people of town and country become unprincipled.

an4.70:1.4.eng: When the people of town and country are unprincipled, the courses of the moon and sun become erratic.

an4.70:1.5.pli: Visamaṃ candimasūriyesu parivattantesu visamaṃ nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni parivattanti.
an4.70:1.5.eng: … the courses of the stars and constellations …

an4.70:1.6.pli: Visamaṃ nakkhattesu tārakarūpesu parivattantesu visamaṃ rattindivā parivattanti.

an4.70:1.7.pli: Visamaṃ rattindivesu parivattantesu visamaṃ māsaddhamāsā parivattanti.

an4.70:1.8.pli: Visamaṃ māsaddhamāsesu parivattantesu visamaṃ utusaṃvaccharā parivattanti.
an4.70:1.8.eng: the seasons and years become erratic.

an4.70:1.9.pli: Visamaṃ utusaṃvaccharesu parivattantesu visamaṃ vātā vāyanti visamā apañjasā.
an4.70:1.9.eng: … the blowing of the winds becomes erratic and chaotic.

an4.70:1.10.pli: Visamaṃ vātesu vāyantesu visamesu apañjasesu devatā parikupitā bhavanti.

an4.70:1.11.pli: Devatāsu parikupitāsu devo na sammā dhāraṃ anuppavecchati.
an4.70:1.11.eng: … the heavens don’t provide enough rain.

an4.70:1.12.pli: Deve na sammā dhāraṃ anuppavecchante visamapākāni sassāni bhavanti.

an4.70:1.13.pli: Visamapākāni, bhikkhave, sassāni manussā paribhuñjantā appāyukā honti dubbaṇṇā ca bavhābādhā ca.
an4.70:1.13.eng: When people eat crops that have ripened erratically, they become short-lived, ugly, weak, and sickly.

an4.70:2.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye rājāno dhammikā honti, rājāyuttāpi tasmiṃ samaye dhammikā honti.
an4.70:2.1.eng: At a time when kings are principled, royal officials become principled.

an4.70:2.2.pli: Rājāyuttesu dhammikesu brāhmaṇagahapatikāpi tasmiṃ samaye dhammikā honti.

an4.70:2.3.pli: Brāhmaṇagahapatikesu dhammikesu negamajānapadāpi tasmiṃ samaye dhammikā honti.
an4.70:2.3.eng: people of town and country become principled.

an4.70:2.4.eng: When the people of town and country are principled, the courses of the sun and moon become regular.

an4.70:2.5.pli: Samaṃ candimasūriyesu parivattantesu samaṃ nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni parivattanti.

an4.70:2.6.pli: Samaṃ nakkhattesu tārakarūpesu parivattantesu samaṃ rattindivā parivattanti.

an4.70:2.7.pli: Samaṃ rattindivesu parivattantesu samaṃ māsaddhamāsā parivattanti.

an4.70:2.8.pli: Samaṃ māsaddhamāsesu parivattantesu samaṃ utusaṃvaccharā parivattanti.
an4.70:2.8.eng: the seasons and years become regular.

an4.70:2.9.pli: Samaṃ utusaṃvaccharesu parivattantesu samaṃ vātā vāyanti samā pañjasā.
an4.70:2.9.eng: … the blowing of the winds becomes regular and orderly.

an4.70:2.10.pli: Samaṃ vātesu vāyantesu samesu pañjasesu devatā aparikupitā bhavanti.

an4.70:2.11.pli: Devatāsu aparikupitāsu devo sammā dhāraṃ anuppavecchati.
an4.70:2.11.eng: … the heavens provide plenty of rain.

an4.70:2.12.pli: Deve sammā dhāraṃ anuppavecchante samapākāni sassāni bhavanti.
an4.70:2.12.eng: When the heavens provide plenty of rain, the crops ripen well.

an4.70:2.13.pli: Samapākāni, bhikkhave, sassāni manussā paribhuñjantā dīghāyukā ca honti vaṇṇavanto ca balavanto ca appābādhā cāti.
an4.70:2.13.eng: When people eat crops that have ripened well, they become long-lived, beautiful, strong, and healthy.

an4.70:3.2.eng: if the bull goes off course,

an4.70:3.4.eng: because their leader is off course.

an4.70:4.4.eng: what do you expect the rest to do?

an4.70:6.4.eng: what do you expect the rest to do?

an4.70:6.5.eng: The whole country sleeps at ease,

an4.71:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu apaṇṇakappaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.71:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has four things their practice is unfailing, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.

an4.71:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, paññavā hoti.
an4.71:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, learned, energetic, and wise.

an4.71:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu apaṇṇakappaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṃ khayāyā”ti.
an4.71:1.4.eng: When a mendicant possesses these four things their practice is unfailing, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.”

an4.72:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu apaṇṇakappaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an4.72:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has four things their practice is unfailing, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.

an4.72:1.3.eng: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness; and right view.

an4.72:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu apaṇṇakappaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṃ khayāyā”ti.
an4.72:1.4.eng: When a mendicant possesses these four things their practice is unfailing, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.”

an4.73:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an untrue person can be known by four qualities.

an4.73:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso yo hoti parassa avaṇṇo taṃ apuṭṭhopi pātu karoti, ko pana vādo puṭṭhassa.
an4.73:1.3.eng: To start with, an untrue person speaks ill of another even when not asked, let alone when asked.

an4.73:1.4.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto ahāpetvā alambitvā paripūraṃ vitthārena parassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:1.4.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak ill of another in full detail, not leaving anything out.

an4.73:1.5.eng: That’s how to know that this is an untrue person.

an4.73:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, asappuriso yo hoti parassa vaṇṇo taṃ puṭṭhopi na pātu karoti, ko pana vādo apuṭṭhassa.
an4.73:2.1.eng: Furthermore, an untrue person doesn’t speak well of another even when asked, let alone when not asked.

an4.73:2.2.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto hāpetvā lambitvā aparipūraṃ avitthārena parassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:2.2.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak well of another without giving the full details, leaving many things out.

an4.73:2.3.eng: That’s how to know that this is an untrue person.

an4.73:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, asappuriso yo hoti attano avaṇṇo taṃ puṭṭhopi na pātu karoti, ko pana vādo apuṭṭhassa.
an4.73:3.1.eng: Furthermore, an untrue person doesn’t speak ill of themselves even when asked, let alone when not asked.

an4.73:3.2.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto hāpetvā lambitvā aparipūraṃ avitthārena attano avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:3.2.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak ill of themselves without giving the full details, leaving many things out.

an4.73:3.3.eng: That’s how to know that this is an untrue person.

an4.73:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, asappuriso yo hoti attano vaṇṇo taṃ apuṭṭhopi pātu karoti, ko pana vādo puṭṭhassa.
an4.73:4.1.eng: Furthermore, an untrue person speaks well of themselves even when not asked, let alone when asked.

an4.73:4.2.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto ahāpetvā alambitvā paripūraṃ vitthārena attano vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:4.2.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak well of themselves in full detail, not leaving anything out.

an4.73:4.3.eng: That’s how to know that this is an untrue person.

an4.73:4.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato asappuriso veditabbo.
an4.73:4.4.eng: An untrue person can be known by these four qualities.

an4.73:5.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato sappuriso veditabbo.
an4.73:5.1.eng: A true person can be known by four qualities.

an4.73:5.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso yo hoti parassa avaṇṇo taṃ puṭṭhopi na pātu karoti, ko pana vādo apuṭṭhassa.
an4.73:5.3.eng: To start with, a true person doesn’t speak ill of another even when asked, let alone when not asked.

an4.73:5.4.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto hāpetvā lambitvā aparipūraṃ avitthārena parassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:5.4.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak ill of another without giving the full details, leaving many things out.

an4.73:5.5.eng: That’s how to know that this is a true person.

an4.73:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sappuriso yo hoti parassa vaṇṇo taṃ apuṭṭhopi pātu karoti, ko pana vādo puṭṭhassa.
an4.73:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a true person speaks well of another even when not asked, let alone when asked.

an4.73:6.2.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto ahāpetvā alambitvā paripūraṃ vitthārena parassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:6.2.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak well of another in full detail, not leaving anything out.

an4.73:6.3.eng: That’s how to know that this is a true person.

an4.73:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sappuriso yo hoti attano avaṇṇo taṃ apuṭṭhopi pātu karoti, ko pana vādo puṭṭhassa.
an4.73:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a true person speaks ill of themselves even when not asked, let alone when asked.

an4.73:7.2.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto ahāpetvā alambitvā paripūraṃ vitthārena attano avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:7.2.eng: But when led on by questions they speak ill of themselves in full detail, not leaving anything out.

an4.73:7.3.eng: That’s how to know that this is a true person.

an4.73:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sappuriso yo hoti attano vaṇṇo taṃ puṭṭhopi na pātu karoti, ko pana vādo apuṭṭhassa.
an4.73:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a true person doesn’t speak well of themselves even when asked, let alone when not asked.

an4.73:8.2.pli: Puṭṭho kho pana pañhābhinīto hāpetvā lambitvā aparipūraṃ avitthārena attano vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an4.73:8.2.eng: But when summoned for questioning they speak well of themselves without giving the full details, leaving many things out.

an4.73:8.3.eng: That’s how to know that this is a true person.

an4.73:8.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato sappuriso veditabbo.
an4.73:8.4.eng: A true person can be known by these four qualities.

an4.73:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, vadhukā yaññadeva rattiṃ vā divaṃ vā ānītā hoti, tāvadevassā tibbaṃ hirottappaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sassuyāpi sasurepi sāmikepi antamaso dāsakammakaraporisesu.
an4.73:9.1.eng: It’s like a bride on the day or night she’s first brought to her husband’s home. Right away she sets up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for her mother and father in law, her husband, and even the bondservants, workers, and staff.

an4.73:9.2.pli: Sā aparena samayena saṃvāsamanvāya vissāsamanvāya sassumpi sasurampi sāmikampi evamāha:
an4.73:9.2.eng: But after some time, because of living together and familiarity, she’ll even say to her mother and father in law, or to her husband:

an4.73:9.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu yaññadeva rattiṃ vā divaṃ vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, tāvadevassa tibbaṃ hirottappaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti bhikkhūsu bhikkhunīsu upāsakesu upāsikāsu antamaso ārāmikasamaṇuddesesu.
an4.73:9.4.eng: In the same way, on the day or night a mendicant first goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, right away they set up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, and even the monastery workers and novices.

an4.73:9.5.pli: So aparena samayena saṃvāsamanvāya vissāsamanvāya ācariyampi upajjhāyampi evamāha:
an4.73:9.5.eng: But after some time, because of living together and familiarity, they’ll even say to their tutor or mentor:

an4.73:9.7.eng: So you should train like this:

an4.73:9.8.eng: ‘We will live with hearts like that of a newly wedded bride.’

an4.74:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things are the best.

an4.74:1.3.eng: The best ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom.

an4.74:1.4.eng: These are the four things that are the best.”

an4.75:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things are the best.

an4.75:1.3.eng: The best form, feeling, perception, and existence.

an4.75:1.4.eng: These are the four things that are the best.”

an4.76:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kusinārāyaṃ viharati upavattane mallānaṃ sālavane antarena yamakasālānaṃ parinibbānasamaye.
an4.76:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā at the time of his full extinguishment.

an4.76:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an4.76:2.1.pli: “Siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, ekabhikkhussapi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā, pucchatha, bhikkhave, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha:
an4.76:2.1.eng: “Perhaps even a single mendicant has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice. So ask, mendicants! Don’t regret it later, thinking:

an4.76:2.2.pli: ‘sammukhībhūto no satthā ahosi, nāsakkhimha bhagavantaṃ sammukhā paṭipucchitun’”ti.
an4.76:2.2.eng: ‘We were in the Teacher’s presence and we weren’t able to ask the Buddha a question.’”

an4.76:2.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
an4.76:2.3.eng: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.

an4.76:3.1.eng: For a second time the Buddha addressed the mendicants: …

an4.76:3.2.pli: “siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, ekabhikkhussapi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā, pucchatha, bhikkhave, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha:

an4.76:3.3.pli: ‘sammukhībhūto no satthā ahosi, nāsakkhimha bhagavantaṃ sammukhā paṭipucchitun’”ti.

an4.76:3.4.pli: Dutiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
an4.76:3.4.eng: For a second time, the mendicants kept silent.

an4.76:4.1.eng: For a third time the Buddha addressed the mendicants: …

an4.76:4.2.pli: “siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, ekabhikkhussapi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā, pucchatha, bhikkhave, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha:

an4.76:4.3.pli: ‘sammukhībhūto no satthā ahosi, nāsakkhimha bhagavantaṃ sammukhā paṭipucchitun’”ti.

an4.76:4.4.pli: Tatiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
an4.76:4.4.eng: For a third time, the mendicants kept silent.

an4.76:5.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

an4.76:5.2.pli: “siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, satthugāravenapi na puccheyyātha, sahāyakopi, bhikkhave, sahāyakassa ārocetū”ti.
an4.76:5.2.eng: “Mendicants, perhaps you don’t ask out of respect for the Teacher. So let a friend tell a friend.”

an4.76:5.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
an4.76:5.3.eng: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.

an4.76:5.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.76:5.4.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

an4.76:5.6.pli: Evaṃ pasanno ahaṃ, bhante. Natthi imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe ekabhikkhussapi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā”ti.
an4.76:5.6.eng: I am quite confident that there’s not even a single mendicant in this Saṅgha who has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice.”

an4.76:6.1.pli: “Pasādā kho tvaṃ, ānanda, vadesi. Ñāṇameva hettha, ānanda, tathāgatassa: ‘natthi imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe ekabhikkhussapi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā’.
an4.76:6.1.eng: “Ānanda, you speak from faith. But the Realized One knows that there’s not even a single mendicant in this Saṅgha who has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice.

an4.76:6.2.pli: Imesañhi, ānanda, pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ yo pacchimako bhikkhu so sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
an4.76:6.2.eng: Even the last of these five hundred mendicants is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

an4.77:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, acinteyyāni, na cintetabbāni; yāni cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa.
an4.77:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things are unthinkable. They should not be thought about, and anyone who tries to think about them will go mad or get frustrated.

an4.77:1.3.pli: Buddhānaṃ, bhikkhave, buddhavisayo acinteyyo, na cintetabbo;

an4.77:1.4.pli: yaṃ cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa.

an4.77:1.5.pli: Jhāyissa, bhikkhave, jhānavisayo acinteyyo, na cintetabbo;
an4.77:1.5.eng: The domain of one in absorption …

an4.77:1.6.pli: yaṃ cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa.

an4.77:1.8.pli: yaṃ cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa.

an4.77:1.10.pli: yaṃ cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa.

an4.77:1.11.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri acinteyyāni, na cintetabbāni; yāni cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
an4.77:1.11.eng: These are the four unthinkable things. They should not be thought about, and anyone who tries to think about them will go mad or get frustrated.”

an4.78:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of purifying a religious donation.

an4.78:1.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakato;
an4.78:1.3.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by the giver, not the recipient.

an4.78:1.4.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā paṭiggāhakato visujjhati, no dāyakato;
an4.78:1.4.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by the recipient, not the giver.

an4.78:1.5.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā neva dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakato;
an4.78:1.5.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by neither the giver nor the recipient.

an4.78:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā dāyakato ceva visujjhati paṭiggāhakato ca.
an4.78:1.6.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by both the giver and the recipient.

an4.78:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakato?
an4.78:2.1.eng: And how is a religious donation purified by the giver, not the recipient?

an4.78:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, dāyako hoti sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo; paṭiggāhakā honti dussīlā pāpadhammā.
an4.78:2.2.eng: It’s when the giver is ethical, of good character, but the recipient is unethical, of bad character.

an4.78:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakato.

an4.78:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā paṭiggāhakato visujjhati, no dāyakato?
an4.78:3.1.eng: And how is a religious donation purified by the recipient, not the giver?

an4.78:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, dāyako hoti dussīlo pāpadhammo; paṭiggāhakā honti sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā.
an4.78:3.2.eng: It’s when the giver is unethical, of bad character, but the recipient is ethical, of good character.

an4.78:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā paṭiggāhakato visujjhati, no dāyakato.

an4.78:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā neva dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakato?
an4.78:4.1.eng: And how is a religious donation purified by neither the giver nor the recipient?

an4.78:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, dāyako hoti dussīlo pāpadhammo; paṭiggāhakāpi honti dussīlā pāpadhammā.
an4.78:4.2.eng: It’s when both the giver and the recipient are unethical, of bad character.

an4.78:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā neva dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakato.

an4.78:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā dāyakato ceva visujjhati paṭiggāhakato ca?
an4.78:5.1.eng: And how is a religious donation purified by both the giver and the recipient?

an4.78:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, dāyako hoti sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo; paṭiggāhakāpi honti sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā.
an4.78:5.2.eng: It’s when both the giver and the recipient are ethical, of good character.

an4.78:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dakkhiṇā dāyakato ceva visujjhati paṭiggāhakato ca.

an4.78:5.4.pli: Imā kho, bhikkhave, catasso dakkhiṇā visuddhiyo”ti.
an4.78:5.4.eng: These are the four ways of purifying a religious donation.”

an4.79:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.79:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an4.79:1.2.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā chedagāminī hoti?
an4.79:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why for different people the same kind of business undertaking might fail,

an4.79:1.3.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā na yathādhippāyā hoti?

an4.79:1.4.pli: Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā yathādhippāyā hoti?

an4.79:1.5.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā parādhippāyā hotī”ti?

an4.79:2.1.pli: “Idha, sāriputta, ekacco samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā pavāreti: ‘vadatu, bhante, paccayenā’ti. So yena pavāreti taṃ na deti.
an4.79:2.1.eng: “Sāriputta, take a case where someone goes to an ascetic or brahmin and invites them to ask for what they need. But they fail to give what’s requested.

an4.79:2.2.pli: So ce tato cuto itthattaṃ āgacchati, so yaññadeva vaṇijjaṃ payojeti, sāssa hoti chedagāminī.
an4.79:2.2.eng: When they’ve passed away from that life, if they’re reborn in this place, whatever business they undertake fails.

an4.79:3.1.pli: Idha pana, sāriputta, ekacco samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā pavāreti: ‘vadatu, bhante, paccayenā’ti. So yena pavāreti taṃ na yathādhippāyaṃ deti.
an4.79:3.1.eng: Take a case where someone goes to an ascetic or brahmin and invites them to ask for what they need. They give what’s requested, but don’t meet expectations.

an4.79:3.2.pli: So ce tato cuto itthattaṃ āgacchati, so yaññadeva vaṇijjaṃ payojeti, sāssa na hoti yathādhippāyā.
an4.79:3.2.eng: When they’ve passed away from that life, if they’re reborn in this place, whatever business they undertake doesn’t meet expectations.

an4.79:4.1.pli: Idha pana, sāriputta, ekacco samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā pavāreti: ‘vadatu, bhante, paccayenā’ti. So yena pavāreti taṃ yathādhippāyaṃ deti.
an4.79:4.1.eng: Take a case where someone goes to an ascetic or brahmin and invites them to ask for what they need. They give what’s requested, meeting expectations.

an4.79:4.2.pli: So ce tato cuto itthattaṃ āgacchati, so yaññadeva vaṇijjaṃ payojeti, sāssa hoti yathādhippāyā.
an4.79:4.2.eng: When they’ve passed away from that life, if they’re reborn in this place, whatever business they undertake meets expectations.

an4.79:5.1.pli: Idha, sāriputta, ekacco samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā pavāreti: ‘vadatu, bhante, paccayenā’ti. So yena pavāreti taṃ parādhippāyaṃ deti.
an4.79:5.1.eng: Take a case where someone goes to an ascetic or brahmin and invites them to ask for what they need. They give what’s requested, exceeding expectations.

an4.79:5.2.pli: So ce tato cuto itthattaṃ āgacchati, so yaññadeva vaṇijjaṃ payojeti, sāssa hoti parādhippāyā.
an4.79:5.2.eng: When they’ve passed away from that life, if they’re reborn in this place, whatever business they undertake exceeds expectations.

an4.79:6.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā chedagāminī hoti.
an4.79:6.1.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why for different people the same kind of business undertaking might fail,

an4.79:6.2.pli: Ayaṃ pana, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā na yathādhippāyā hoti.

an4.79:6.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā yathādhippāyā hoti.

an4.79:6.4.pli: Ayaṃ pana, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekaccassa tādisāva vaṇijjā payuttā parādhippāyā hotī”ti.
